Prospective Resident
Visited 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/07/2017
The staff at Duke Manor was exceptional in getting an apartment. I looked at 10 apartments that day and none of them made me feel as welcomed as Duke Manor. Yenny and Ciera went above and beyond to help me find an apartment just in time for school. I would enthusiastically recommend them to any future residents. Respectfully, Dax Kirkman

Why should we have to pay so much when we really can't do anything because of all the rules they keep adding and when you want to move out they only give you a week to do so. They won't do anything about people not picking up after their dogs. All they want is the money. The maintenance people don't even get me started about them when we had a thunder storm and the roof was leaking I call the office they sent someone a week later all they did was pray paint the ceiling the first time and they didn't even bother to show up the second time it happened. I've never had a problem with roaches until the neighbors moved in and the walls are so thin you can hear them having sex this is just ridiculous. Don't move to duke manor unless you want to be in a prison.

Worst place to live on earth. I moved out 2 month early and gave back my keys. Two months later I get a call from there office looking for the keys. After fighting with them for a bit they found them in their office. On top of that they stole 100% of my deposit and forgot to turn off them water in the apartment when I moved out which cost me an additional $60. They then sent me a bill for addition money due on my water bill and threaten to take me to court for $42 dollars (which they cause by not turning off the water when I moved out), which would of ruined my credit score. DO NOT live here unless you are a drug addict, drug dealer, or not from this country because that is 100% of the remaining population.

Resident
2015 - 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/04/2016
I don't know where to begin. The staff is disrespectful and unprofessional. They give no notice for maintenance and the 'maintenance' they do perform is shoddy and probably performed without permits. They cut corners at every opportunity and raise the rent with no notice and without explanation. Most recently, the contractors hired broke a city water main at about 4:30 pm and after working on it for a few hours, left the problem unresolved all night, leaving hundreds of residents without water for over 12 hours. The issue still has not been fixed at 7:30 am the following day. The office staff has been trained to be incompetent, or so it would seem, as simple questions are apparently impossible to answer. Just in under a year we have had dozens of problems, including a leak in the roof, which maintenance refused to fix for weeks. We returned to the office daily for weeks, and the office staff blatantly lied to our faces daily, saying "Maintenance will be there today." Absolutely atrocious. I would under no circumstances recommend this apartment complex. They host events for the community every few months and expect that to make up for insufficient customer service. I have tolerated all the other issues, but the broken water main and the apartment's decision to just allow hundreds of residents to be without water for over 12 hours (so far--will update as the day progresses!) [EDIT: It has been over 24 hours!] is unacceptable. There is nothing salvageable about the experience here. Without a staff that is willing to do their jobs, nothing will change. Please also notice how a vast majority of positive reviews were written 8/04/15... as other reviewers have stated, there is a monetary incentive to leave a positive review, and clearly residents were told so at the block party hosted on that day. So transparent.

Resident
2012 - 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/17/2016
"EXPLOITATION OF THE POOR" I scarcely know where to begin......Please note, Durham Herald and the City Council will be informed after the petition is finalized calling for external oversight and investigation into the unlawful acts being perpetrated against less than affluent Latinos and African-Americans by this "slumlord'. There's documented evidence of Latino families being forced out of their apartments under the guise of "renovation" with minimum notice and they're made to pay more money monthly as a consequence or experience homelessness as an alternative. Duke Manor Apartments in specific and GSC in general needs to fasten their seat belts and batten down their hatches because a storm is coming and they can't get a late start. I suggest they familiarize themselves with the "Fair Housing Act" that federally protects one against discrimination and these financially deceitful cut-throat tactics. They are basking in an environment of potential lawsuits they've created for themselves because of their greed and oppression and "exploitation of poor people". Also, legal representation is forthcoming as well. The 4 year old roach and bed bug "unresolved problem" is a given along with the repetitive maintenance request to fix an AC/furnace adequately to no avail. The inability to have guest because of fear of their vehicles being towed by a leech-like towing company (Chandlers) is akin to simply being "bloodsuckers of the poor". The elevated broken treadmill in the fitness facility that has not been fixed in several months. The residents speeding thru the complexes as if it's highway 40 and my child nearly being hit as a result and suggestions to management for more speed bumps have fallen on deaf ears (they're itching for a lawsuit). The office staff (women) seemingly more concerned with trying to be beguiling to the men and dressing like their going to a club or disco rather than being professional and addressing the concerns of the tenants. The robberies, shootings and perpetual drug dealing/activity is also a given and management turns a blind eye to any information or suggestions because they do not live here and they won't because it's not safe. There's more, but that comes later. There's legal work to be performed and the newspapers will soon reflect this story in no uncertain terms, guaranteed!

Resident
2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 11/22/2015
This is, by far, the WORST apartment complex I have ever lived in. I moved in January 2015 and have regretted it since. I have had a constant problem with roaches. The office does quarterly extermination with some spray that is very sticky and does not work. The walls are super thin and you can hear the neighbors urinate! It is very poorly insulated and my electricity for a 560 square foot apartment is on average $100 per month!! They tow your car if you don't have a parking pass and they change the rules and don't let you know. The office corresponds by putting papers next to the doorknob so anyone could read it or the wind could blow it away. The worst of it is the neighborhood. In the past few months, there have been at LEAST ten robberies/break-ins and one robber was killed in self defense. These crimes are becoming more frequent and it is terrifying. The have ONE security guard who sits in his car. How is that going to keep all these people safe?!? I am a white female who lives alone and do not feel safe. I cannot wait to move out. The office workers are near impossible to get a hold of. There have been numerous times I have called like ten times in row before I got a person on the phone. The buildings are ugly. The apartment is very small and they want to increase my rent substantially. I pay $560 and they would raise it to $710 if I did not sign a lease and to $590 if I did. This place is not worth $560, nevermind $590. STAY AWAY! I lived in a nice apartment years ago owned by Ticon Properties and had a great place. Try them and stay away from properties like this owned by GSC.

Report
Resident
2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/24/2015
The apartments themselves aren't too bad, but management has put into place an absurd and stifling parking policy. You essentially aren't allowed to have guests over in the evening unless you coordinate in advance with the leasing office and obtain temporary guest passes that your guests need to place in their car; even then, your guests can't arrive in more than 2 cars. Otherwise, their cars will be towed by the 3rd party towing company that prowls the apartment complex every night. There's plenty of parking available - the policy makes no sense. I cannot recommend living here to anyone but a hermit. Those writing about crime problems, fake reviews, etc., are all absolutely correct. There are frequent burglaries/shootings, and people are being bribed to write good reviews. Crazy that they would pay that kind of money for a good review, but won't fix a broken policy to get one. Also, note that walls are paper thin (despite the lead paint in the walls, which they don't tell you about until you're signing lease paperwork). I can hear my neighbor's xbox turn on. That isn't a loud noise that should be carrying through a wall.

Report
Resident
2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/20/2015
My girlfriend and I moved here from Louisiana this past Summer in May. We saw positive reviews online and thought to check it out. We went and viewed the place and they moved us in the same day, which I thought was peculiar but at the time we were pressed to find a place so we thought nothing of it. Looking back I should have known they. In their defense they are trying to turn the place around, but the current tenants will never let that happen. The area is unsafe and people are up all night doing god knows what. It is extremely loud at all time of the day until about 1 am - 6 am and then the noise resumes. When you try to be decent and politely ask people to turn their BLARING sound systems down they yell at you, first in english then promptly in spanish. If you call the office nothing gets done. They have a courtesy officer on standby by at all times but he never resolves any problems. Maintenance is fast here and they do their job but they don't have much to work with. The units themselves are redone, but pretty cheaply renovated. They have a nice look but there is no storage space in the 1 bedrooms. No place to put dry foods, we stored most of ours above the stove and on top of the fridge. Don't bring a lot of dishes or you're screwed. Not a lot of storage in the bathroom either, and we had a lot of tub drainage problems, constantly. Also a lot of problems with our ac constantly going out. All in all we were there for 3 months and promptly moved out. I DO NOT recommend this place unless you are looking for drugs or you're single and never home and an extremely deep sleeper. Terrible for families or people who want to enjoy their free time. 2/10

They have a courtesy officer on standby by at all times but he never resolves any problems. Maintenance is fast here and they do their job but they don't have much to work with. The units themselves are redone, but pretty cheaply renovated. They have a nice look but there is no storage space in the 1 bedrooms. No place to put dry foods, we stored most of ours above the stove and on top of the fridge. Don't bring a lot of dishes or you're screwed. Not a lot of storage in the bathroom either, and we had a lot of tub drainage problems, constantly. Also a lot of problems with our ac constantly going out. All in all we were there for 3 months and promptly moved out. I DO NOT recommend this place unless you are looking for drugs or you're single and never home and an extremely deep sleeper. Terrible for families or people who want to enjoy their free time. 2/10 Read less

2015 Recommended Property Reviewed 07/27/2015
I was looking for an apartment, where I could stay during my next two years of study at Duke. Everything was so expensive, but Duke Manor did not. In comparison to Belmont or Trinity Commons, which are just 5 minutes walking (and literally across the fence), it is 2x cheaper at least. When I made a reservation and came to see the place, I was surprised that the quality was very good. I've been at apartments of my classmates, who live at Belmont, and Duke Manor is not worse, while the price is at least 2x times lower! Moreover, as a student I had not to pay my rental fee for the first months. It is some special discount at Duke Manor this year. And for this money I have a fully 2015 renovated apartment and it goes with new washer/dryer and steal kitchen appliances, and the rooms themselves are in a very good condition. No bugs or something. My special thanks go to Duke Manor's leasing agent Maria, who was so helpful with move in! He made it smooth and easy. And talking about the service. During my first month as a resident I had only one issue. The washer drain pipe was blocked. However, I called leasing office and they sent me a handy man and he fixed everything the same day. So, from my experience, service is perfect! In conclusion, I can recommend Duke Manor as very good place for living. I bet, you won't find better price-quality place in Durham. Zhenya

Resident
2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/29/2014
I've been living at Duke Manor for almost a two months now, and so far it has been great. The community itself is pretty active, you always see people walking around, at the fitness center, or hanging out by the pool. It isn't the most quiet apartment community that I have lived in, but the activity noise isn't that of loud music and parties, just neighbors out and about talking and laughing. I will say that the exterior appearance of the apartment complexes are not the most visually appealing, but the interior layout and design makes up for it. Duke Manor is currently going through a lot of interior modifications/renovations so they do have updated and non updated apartment options. The updates (which I rent out) is a little more expensive, but comes with newer appliances, countertops, hardwood floors, and a few other things. The living crowd here seems pretty divers. I've seen college students, families, and bachelors (like me) all living here. In all, I've been happy here so far.

Resident
2012 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/27/2014
I lived in Duke Manor during my senior year of undergrad. I will agree and say that this community isn't the nicest, cleanest, or in the best area of town, but hey the rates were very managable for a college student with a roommate. I would definitely recommend having a roommate, because otherwise this place isn't that affordable for a college student. The location was prime in that I could bike to school on nice days or take the bus (which has a pickup at Duke Manor) on rainy or cold days. This community also has a pool and gym, which I rarely used but always appeared to be in use by others. The floorplan was pretty open and fair with the bedroom sizes which were actually a solid size for an apartment bedroom. A complaint I have is that the washer and dryer were located in the closet of the master bedroom which occasionally bothered my roommate when I would have to walk in his room to do my laundry. Another complaint is that your vehicle has a good chance of being towed if you don't have the parking tag. This got annoying when I would have friends over at first, but once I learned you could get a visitor tag from the office the issue was solved. I guess the towing can also be a benefit since I always had a spot in front of my unit. Overall Duke Manor fit my needs at an exceptable price. I would recommend this place for all college students.

Resident
2013 - 2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 03/17/2014
HORRIBLE! We chose this complex because it was very cheap and within walking distance of my school. Worst. Decision. Ever. All repairs are done with minimal effort and poor workmanship. We can hear everything our neighbors are saying and the music they are listening to. The single pane windows make heating and cooling the unit impossible and lets in an insane amount of noise from the parking lot. We had to buy our own insulating material just to make it through this cold winter. 95% of the weatherstripping on our front door is gone and after 2 months of requesting it from the maintenance department I've about given up. The girl who answers the phone in the maintenance department is rude and not very bright. It takes several days to receive a call-back from a very simple message. The workmen are always very nice and professional, but the work they do is sub-par. Repairs consist of "band-aid" fixes rather than true repairs. An upstairs neighbor caused a leak and we experienced water damage on our ceiling as a result. It took 2 weeks for maintenance to come out and fix it and instead of repairing it, it was just painted over. I know there is a mold issue within the walls/ceilings because my allergies have been awful since living here, but clear up when I'm away for a day or two. The ceiling above our shower is so damage and poorly repaired that you can push it up almost 2 inches. It started to crumble in a few days ago and was repaired by yet another layer of mud and paint. We keep our unit spotless so that we can fend off the bugs, but after a building-wide extermination we encountered nasty, disgusting roaches. The area under our kitchen sink is a scary eyesore that I try to avoid. The "new and improved" fitness center is a joke. Half of the weight machines don't work, there are two treadmills, but only one "works" and it shocks you the entire time you're running. None of the noise, clean breezeway, or car maintenance in the parking lot rules are enforced. Every weekend results in at least 5 different cars being "fixed" in the parking lot. Speaking of the parking lot, they're all patched poorly (or not at all) and the spots are all different sizes (some that don't even fit a small car) and crooked. I cannot express enough how awful this place is. Don't move here!!!

Resident
2012 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/22/2013
I chose Duke Manor because the apartments are very affordable, and the location is perfect for me. The Duke Transit takes me directly to campus for my classes. I frequently use Duke Manor s soccer field and fitness center to stay in shape for my club sports. After my workouts, I ll occasionally cool off and relax by the swimming pool. The community is pretty large and has many worthwhile features, so I am surprised that the rent is so low. My apartment has sufficient space and seems to be well-built (nothing has broken down or stopped working). The only minor issue I can think of is the exterior appearance of the community. The building walls look a little old, and the overall area looks a little dull. I feel like planting more trees would help enliven the place a bit. Nonetheless, Duke Manor is a great value and I would definitely recommend it, especially to other students in the area.

I ended my lease early and paid alot of money but I didnt have to live with bugs any longer and that was my main concern. GRRRRrrr... I HATED living there with a passion!!!! Security was rude, I had a guest who went to work out with me and security kicked her out because she didnt live there so i to left with my company and went to the YMCA. It was sooooooooo noisy I was going to call the police but I didnt want drama with my neighbor so I didnt call. My neighbors were really rude and disrespectful and inconsiderate. The grounds are terrible and have poop EVERYWHERE!! My toilet was broke and flooded my bathroom and I had a 1 bedroom 1 bathroom apartment. Being pregnant I had to use the bathroom alot and couldnt go. Most of the staff doesnt speak english. Parking was the only good thing.

Report
Resident
2011 - 2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 12/27/2012
I believe GSC properties has a history of bad wiring and not doing anything productive about it. A co-worker rented a townhouse from GSC in Raleigh, NC. My unit alone had three separate outlets that had sparks coming out of them, a maintenance man who i had to let in my house tried to get me to come over his apartment, only repaired the outlets enough to stop the sparks, but by the surges and flickers, it seems pretty obvious they have some serious faulty wiring. This could be from the cracks in the outside walls where the building has settled and is no longer properly supported by the foundation, from the crappy self-remodeling to squeeze more tenants in. When I first moved in, I was walking my dog and trying to avoid crossing in front of a white maintenance van, with ladders on its roof, passing through the parking lot behind my apartment. Intentionally, he slowed down his van so much I had to cross in front of him. I do not speak to people I don't know, multiple people tell me I look as though I am about to START college, and a few kids have told me I look high school (their age) age, so I make it a point to leave strangers alone, especially old men. This dude said something to me, I had my iPod on (clearly had headphones in my ears, it was July) I glanced at him and kept walking until I noticed he was opening his van door. I stopped and stepped back and he proceeded to get out of the van saying something. I was startled and must have looked it, I paused my music and heard him say as he took another step towards me, "it's rude not to answer someone when he speaks to you". not sure how i phrased it, but i'm pretty sure i told him he doesn't know me and i don't owe him anything. He looked over my shoulder, looked back at me and jumped into the van. Directly behind were apartment buildings and i now believe either someone looked out the window or was coming out the house and that caused him to drive away. A few months ago, one maintenance worker woke me up from across the parking lot. It was about ten past seven in the morning and when I looked out the window, I could see the problem. He had his truck doors open and his radio blasting some rock song and he was just puttering around outside. My windows were closed, the curtains drawn, but every word, every chord was clearly intelligible. The music has only happened once. But other mornings, at 6, sometimes 7, they have left out the maintenance building, shouting to each other, which is also clearly heard through the walls. Remember in the early morning even normal voices can be heard through walls. I worked nights when I was pregnant, so waking up at 7 a.m. while pregnant is very difficult. And it is not always easy to go back to sleep. If I had known this was first and foremost a workplace for the different staffs, rather than a home for the residents who are paying the staff, I would have rented a box by the rail road first. At least there you expect bad wiring, or no wiring, water problems, lock problems, loud neighbors, absent minded to careless staff members. Which I do want to say out of the office staff and maintenance staff, I have met at least three in each department that I really like, individually. They do good work and do their best to treat you like a human versus a paycheck. You are required to pay a water bill, but not to Durham County, but to some company in FL that is either owned by GSC or owns GSC, either way they are unwilling to furnish any sort of metered documentation that shows exactly how much water you use/sewage you flush. In July, when renewing the lease, they told us the extra trash collection fee would be included in the rent. Over the phone a month ago, they said the trash collection fee is in the water bill. So which is it? Apparently it depends on who you talk to. You can pay your water bill to Duke Manor. So either Duke Manor, GSC, or NES, but, oddly, never the people who actually supply the water. They said they would be re-paving the parking lots. They patched some areas and then merely sprayed black paint over the rest. Which stank, through the windows, for a couple of weeks. They offer online rental payments, but the option does not actually work, at least for our apartment. Which is actually even worse. They installed new washer and dryers in the laundromat (where you will find either homeless people or unsupervised small children screaming and running and not caring if they are in your way) from Caldwell & Gregory, no change machine, only a cash to card option that was supposed to let you add money online, the minimum amount is $20, so it is still necessary to get quarters, since they let the cash to card machine fill up before most Saturday mornings, leaving the cash to card machine useless all weekend. Even when there are kids with their parents in the laundromat, the kids are assisted onto the clean laundry folding counters and benches by their parents so they can run around on them instead of the floor, or ignored by their parents. I was there before the new machines and a representative from Caldwell & Gregory asked me what I would like to see, I said a machine that can wash blankets. He informed me they were installing one front load, maybe two. So I assumed, in the flow of our conversation, that the front load would be the answer to my prompted suggestion. Now if you call their maintenance line they explain the front loaders are not really meant for heavy duty loads like blankets, towels and jeans. At least not in abundance...... On the weekends it is impossible to do any laundry, opt for Wednesday-Friday morning. Over the weekend, most especially on Sundays, people will use six to eight machines that once the time runs out on them, they sit full of clothes, wet in the washers, dry in the dryers for hours. This past Sunday, my husband said in the whole time he did my laundry, about two hours, six of the dryers just had clothes sitting in them. I did my household laundry, towels and wash clothes, after him and he came to help me carry home and mentioned that the occupied but non running machines were not only the same ones as before, but had the same clothes in them. Apparently, on the weekend some people have actually bought the washers and dryers as personal items and do not feel any sort of responsibility or accountability to other residents. And this is a big complex. It seems obvious someone besides yourself would need to do laundry. Our neighbors did not let us use the walkway. They have placed two grills and a couch in the middle of the only walkway to our house from the sidewalk, I have spoken to someone in the office who has told me they care, but it has been a week and the two grills are still in the way. Update: It wasn't until the end of December 2012, after the 26th, was anything to be done. I have pictures with time stamps. And emails. The people above us, also in a one bed room, have a small child, who I have found out since becoming pregnant, that they NEVER take outside,unless transporting. they fully let him run around and jump around ALL day as though they live on the first floor. December 31, 2012, he ran heavily and jumped off things onto the floor or simply jumped on the floor pretty much non stop for 15 hours. As I was 24 weeks pregnant, it made it very difficult to sleep when i was tired as every time i settled down, he would appear above my head jumping onto the floor, so it sounded as though he was just right on top of me. Just for a reference as to how thin the walls and floors/ceilings are, we get up at 4:00 a.m. and it is quiet enough that when our neighbors next to us or above us talk, we can hear their voices. So jumping is quite loud. They lived here before we did, so for two, almost three years, we have listened to them and the other day at 7:00 a.m. two Saturdays ago, their child jumped onto the floor above our heads, not once but twice. By the second time I was in the living room grabbing a blanket due to the cold and climbing up the buildings rickety, loud stairs and knocking on their window and door. We have never said anything to them the whole time we lived here other than "hello" and this encounter was long overdue. The parents seemed upset I was bothering them, as though they couldn't understand what I was doing up there. Still half asleep I asked them if there was a problem with me sleeping. Don't think I mentioned the noise, maybe I did, if so it was something like so why is there ALWAYS jumping above us and loud crashes and when we try to knock on the ceiling to let them know, passively, they are being too rude for too long, they stomp on the floor extra hard for about a minute. The man looked mad and said his son fell. Well since it happened twice (and I've lived in two story houses and other apartments) I knew either he fell HARD or he jumped. So I played along and asked him, is your son alright? Since I HATE people who use their children as an excuse for bad manners. He got mad and said he's fine and shut the door in my face. So I told my family, if he's acting like that and claims the child fell rather than jumped, maybe the Child Services needs to get involved. The neighbor next to them is wonderful. The one next to him ( on the top floor, in the middle ) has quieted down some, but she has occasionally, and for a while often, verbally and physically abuse her friend/boyfriend , once with a plastic bucket. She is pregnant now and that furthers her belief that that means whether it is 12:00a.m. or 4:00a.m., this morning in April 2013 it was more like 3:30a.m., she can go outside to either the shared walkway and/staircases, with her boyfriend, and holler across the parking lot to her boyfriend, while he goes to his car. Every Saturday, it is as though our neighbors work together to make sure you don't sleep past the full sunrise. Another tenant has begun letting their dog out while it is dark, morning and night, and not having it either on a leash or being outside with it. It tries to run me, my husband and my dog off from OUR HOUSE. i love animals, but whoever the ------- is that owns this mutt deserves whatever happens to unsupervised, unfriendly animals. He looks nearly starved. I've tried calling Animal Control but it is run through the Sheriff's department now and they could care less there's a stray dog that might have a disease in an apartment complex full of children. When we first moved in, they tried to claim our beagle mix was partially doberman. they tried to fine us on top of the $200 pet deposit (which is not a deposit, you do not get that money back even if the apartment is in good order, according to the leasing agent we spoke with. So less of a deposit and more of simply a fee). In the next three months, after we first moved in, we saw at least five other large dogs that were clearly pit bull mixes moved in near us and nothing was ever said to those owners about those restricted breed dogs. Currently there is a young gentleman with the most gorgeous pit mix in our building or nearby, he's well behaved, good looking, but definitely a pit bull. Yet they thought our 18 lb. dog was the threat. They will tell you they care, but when push comes to shove, they are looking for the least amount of work. The people above us blocked up our shower drain within the first couple of months living here. We had Shawn snake the drain and we bought lots of Dran-o. No one showed up until Friday night, and not in response to our mid-week maintenance call but because of the neighbors' complaint. For a week, every time the shower above us stopped running, our tub would fill up, from the drain, with dirty, stink water, which I would wait for it to drain so I could wash it. Then wait for that to drain so I could rinse it. I was washing the tub about two or three times a day. A man came in every day over the weekend to fix the problem. So for two days we had a hole in our bathroom wall because of the people above us and someone in our bathroom. Our next door neighbors had the same hole and we could hear the maintenance man going upstairs to the apartment above us also. There is no seal or insulation around the windows so during the winter or summer, once you open your blinds and curtains, you can feel the temperature outside from three feet away. During the winter, once i do open the blinds and curtains, no matter what time, within five minutes, the heat kicks on. The door is hung crooked in the frame and is not actually the same size as the doorway. There is a 1 inch gap along the bottom between the door and the door way. Last year a resident was attacked and allegedly raped on property while taking the trash out. Because the crime was thought to be perpetrated by another resident, we were not informed and I had to hear about this safety hazard from a security officer, who thank God, worried more about citizen safety then the crap Duke Manor told him. Other apartment complexes are having robbery problems but that is not something Duke Manor warns their residents about, though the other complexes hear about the crime in Duke Manor, and their own complexes, from their own complex. In fact, Duke Manor invite people from their other apartment complexes to use the pool, weight room and i guess the laundromat. There are guard houses at the entrances but they are unmanned and the barriers lift for any and everyone no matter which entrance you use nor does it matter when. So it's gated like Diet Coke is a healthy diet drink. Update: As of January 3, my husband and I lost our baby. It was tragic and came at a horrible time. There is no known reason, whether it was a broken genetic prevention on nature's part, stress from our lives or simply a lesson we needed to learn, the point is, my parents came up to help me since we don't have a car and tried to get us moved to a different apartment given the stress I have here. My mother is unable to stay with me all the time and needs to be with my father and my husband has his own familial obligations. The office staff is always trying to ask questions about my parents and where they live. We do not live like most of the world I guess, but times are tight and, as family, we are all trying to help each other when and how we can. We do not feel it is GSC's business what we do. My parents made more than one appointment with a woman in the office, we do know the name of her but will not say it, to change the apartment but each time they went in or tried to call her she was busy. Although she did make it very clear I had to take down this review online. So i don't know if my refusal to remove this was why they were so busy and never even returned my mother's call or if they just stopped caring about the issue. Since my family has been in mourning, they really haven't been on my mind. The next time I went to the office to pay my rent, one lady helped me and she was quite nice and helpful. For some reason, as I left, I noticed all the other office women huddled in their kitchen area whispering and looking over at me. Not one of them offered a smile or wave. So since January, I have asked my brother, my husband and I will begin asking friends to go into the office for me. I am not a side show and I will not be stared at. A couple of decorating tips. The model apartment is beautiful. Lots of light, open space, finished cabinets. Our actual apartment is full of more dust than any of us have seen in Philadelphia, NY, Boston, FL (places I've lived) and other Durham apartments and houses. We think it is the ventilation system someone installed. The cabinets in the kitchen do not only have crooked doors but one of them is actually broken just not in a way that is immediately obvious. There is no baseboard along the bottom of one of the cabinets. The space under the kitchen sink is saggy, as is the space under the bathroom sink. The dishwasher counter is unfinished and very noisy since the side of the dishwasher is visible once you move the stove. Little thing: the stove clock has NEVER worked and I have taped over it to "stop" the blinking. The areas they tack the carpet down, you can feel the sharp tacks if you're barefoot. The door locks are old, they stop working after a while and even with your house key you are locked in. A maintenance man just came over to change my lock and let me out of my house. He was very professional and prompt. I've lived in other apartments and houses and never had a problem leaving my house. I looked at the new bolt he installed and see it is not really the lock but the crooked door that is the problem, at least now, maybe the old lock was kaput. The door is not properly aligned with the lock hole and so it is easier to unlock the bolt when the door is open, once the door is in the jamb, you can feel the difference in the ease of the new lock. Ah well. At least I can leave when I want. It's interesting, if you call after hours with a maintenance issue, they have a serious phone list to go through about what could be the problem. So they are HIGHLY aware of what's broken here, but it's too bad there are so many known and on going issues they are aware of. Yes they actively fix things, but they do not pro actively prevent things from breaking. And again, this is all thanks to GSC's management decisions, not Duke Manor, unless of course this is some weird real estate franchise or something. It's a shame the answer to this complex is in it being shut down instead of fixed up. They recently did something to one of the "guard houses" at the entrance. Both my husband and myself saw the work being done. But now the workers are gone, we are having a difficult time figuring out what they did, they most we can figure is, they re-grouted the bricks. But again, our windows are not insulated. On a utilities note, our neighbors, who have one more person living with them than we do, pay half what we do to NES, the utility company in FL responsible for tracking our water usage and billing us. Again, they do not send out usage reports, simply bills. One month we bought nothing but bottled water for everything except showering. Our bill actually went up a few dollars that month. Another neighbor in anther building has the same issues, but they actually didn't even stay there for a few weeks, apparently they used the same amount of water. Light bills are $100 or more for a one bedroom. I've lived in two story houses in NEW ENGLAND and the comparison is ludicrous. We spent another month, keeping lights off and bundling up and trying not to use the heat, started taking lukewarm showers, same thing. No change in usage worth more than $10... So who is really using our electricity?? But of course, if you ask the office people, they will tell you this is all untrue, just like they told my family at the beginning of the new year.

There is no known reason, whether it was a broken genetic prevention on nature's part, stress from our lives or simply a lesson we needed to learn, the point is, my parents came up to help me since we don't have a car and tried to get us moved to a different apartment given the stress I have here. My mother is unable to stay with me all the time and needs to be with my father and my husband has his own familial obligations. The office staff is always trying to ask questions about my parents and where they live. We do not live like most of the world I guess, but times are tight and, as family, we are all trying to help each other when and how we can. We do not feel it is GSC's business what we do. My parents made more than one appointment with a woman in the office, we do know the name of her but will not say it, to change the apartment but each time they went in or tried to call her she was busy. Although she did make it very clear I had to take down this review online. So i don't know if my refusal to remove this was why they were so busy and never even returned my mother's call or if they just stopped caring about the issue. Since my family has been in mourning, they really haven't been on my mind. The next time I went to the office to pay my rent, one lady helped me and she was quite nice and helpful. For some reason, as I left, I noticed all the other office women huddled in their kitchen area whispering and looking over at me. Not one of them offered a smile or wave. So since January, I have asked my brother, my husband and I will begin asking friends to go into the office for me. I am not a side show and I will not be stared at. A couple of decorating tips. The model apartment is beautiful. Lots of light, open space, finished cabinets. Our actual apartment is full of more dust than any of us have seen in Philadelphia, NY, Boston, FL (places I've lived) and other Durham apartments and houses. We think it is the ventilation system someone installed. The cabinets in the kitchen do not only have crooked doors but one of them is actually broken just not in a way that is immediately obvious. There is no baseboard along the bottom of one of the cabinets. The space under the kitchen sink is saggy, as is the space under the bathroom sink. The dishwasher counter is unfinished and very noisy since the side of the dishwasher is visible once you move the stove. Little thing: the stove clock has NEVER worked and I have taped over it to "stop" the blinking. The areas they tack the carpet down, you can feel the sharp tacks if you're barefoot. The door locks are old, they stop working after a while and even with your house key you are locked in. A maintenance man just came over to change my lock and let me out of my house. He was very professional and prompt. I've lived in other apartments and houses and never had a problem leaving my house. I looked at the new bolt he installed and see it is not really the lock but the crooked door that is the problem, at least now, maybe the old lock was kaput. The door is not properly aligned with the lock hole and so it is easier to unlock the bolt when the door is open, once the door is in the jamb, you can feel the difference in the ease of the new lock. Ah well. At least I can leave when I want. It's interesting, if you call after hours with a maintenance issue, they have a serious phone list to go through about what could be the problem. So they are HIGHLY aware of what's broken here, but it's too bad there are so many known and on going issues they are aware of. Yes they actively fix things, but they do not pro actively prevent things from breaking. And again, this is all thanks to GSC's management decisions, not Duke Manor, unless of course this is some weird real estate franchise or something. It's a shame the answer to this complex is in it being shut down instead of fixed up. They recently did something to one of the "guard houses" at the entrance. Both my husband and myself saw the work being done. But now the workers are gone, we are having a difficult time figuring out what they did, they most we can figure is, they re-grouted the bricks. But again, our windows are not insulated. On a utilities note, our neighbors, who have one more person living with them than we do, pay half what we do to NES, the utility company in FL responsible for tracking our water usage and billing us. Again, they do not send out usage reports, simply bills. One month we bought nothing but bottled water for everything except showering. Our bill actually went up a few dollars that month. Another neighbor in anther building has the same issues, but they actually didn't even stay there for a few weeks, apparently they used the same amount of water. Light bills are $100 or more for a one bedroom. I've lived in two story houses in NEW ENGLAND and the comparison is ludicrous. We spent another month, keeping lights off and bundling up and trying not to use the heat, started taking lukewarm showers, same thing. No change in usage worth more than $10... So who is really using our electricity?? But of course, if you ask the office people, they will tell you this is all untrue, just like they told my family at the beginning of the new year. Read less

2011 - 2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/25/2012
I moved into Duke Manor knowing I was moving into one of the cheapest places in Durham, but my standards were low and I thought I could manage for a year. IT IS NOT WORTH IT! We ended up spending for more money with all the problems created by living here then we did save because of the cheap rent. CONS: Bedbugs: we were forced to throw away all of our furniture when we moved out because we were infested. Even after the utmost precaution, having the apartment exterminator come, we never got rid of them. It was sickening knowing you had to go to bed and wake up with bites all over your body. Cockroaches: Despite them spraying and all over out prevention, we had problems with these the entire year. Noise: We were very tolerant of noise, but it was just so excesive. Music, yelling all hours of the day and night. We could hear normal conversation levels from our neighbors because of paper thin walls. Saftey: We were never broken into, but did receive several notices while living there to be on alert because of break ins and robberies within the complex. More concerning, there is absolutely not screening process for residents, and as a result we were physically threatened (at random before even meeting) one of our neighbors who turned out to be very disturbed, and very scary to live next too. I didn't feel comfortable being in my apartment alone because of my neighbor. Summary: Yes, it is cheap. And they do a good job making the outside look nice. But the expenses and stress of living in such an environment completely out ways any money you save.

Resident
2006 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/21/2007
My wife and I lived at Duke Manor for about 3 months when we first moved to Durham while we looked for a house. It fit our needs perfectly - we wanted a place close to Duke's campus with really low rent (needed to save money for the down payment....I think our rent for a one-bedroom was $420 or something like that) and would be willing to let you rent on a flexible month-to-month basis. We called almost all apartment complexes nearby and this was the only place that was able to provide all these things for us. Many other posters have mentioned crime - we never had any problem with crime, but we were only there for 3 months. The apartment did have a major cockroach problem - the management sprayed twice while we were there, but they still survived. I do wish I knew Spanish so I could get to know some of our neighbors better though.

Report
Resident
1999 - 2000 Not Recommended Reviewed 04/15/2003
Pros: convenience, price <br><br> <br><br>Cons: safety, community, upkeep, staff <br><br> <br><br>Duke Manor looks great on paper. They have apartments for under $350/mo, they´re within walking distance of Duke, there´s shuttle service to Duke, and they have two pools and a weight room. That´s all true. But just about everything else there is bad. <br><br> <br><br>My earliest complaint about Duke Manor was the staff. It took them two months -- with frequent prodding by me -- to process my rent application. I had a flawless tenancy record and great credit -- they just sat on my application for two months. <br><br> <br><br>The building I moved into had burned just months before I moved in, a fact that the staff didn´t share with me. On the plus side, that meant all new carpets and paint (though not new appliances). On the down side, it meant that we had no phone lines. It took me several days just to secure staff permission to get a phone line running in through my living room window, and weeks more to get the inside wiring fixed. Even once the phone lines were fixed, they were noisy: I couldn´t get DSL, and my modem never worked above 14.4K. <br><br> <br><br>Safety is a pretty significant concern at Duke Manor, too. It´s in a fairly bad part of Durham, so there are frequent thefts and occasional gunshots. There was a homocide not long after I moved out. The parking lots are lit, there´s a fence around the whole community, and a security guy drives by occasionally, but it´s somehow not enough. I never really felt safe outside at night. Strangers knocked on my door at all hours. I ended up putting in a peep-hole (which Duke Manor should have provided, but didn´t) so that I could avoid opening the door for strangers. <br><br> <br><br>The maintenance staff was OK. They usually came within a few days (except for the phone wiring), and they only refused to fix one problem with the drier. <br><br> <br><br>After an unusually severe snowstorm, our gutter broke. They still hadn´t fixed it properly when I moved out six months later. <br><br> <br><br>Construction was OK. The walls were thin, so I could hear my annoying neighbor´s music, but that has happened in nearly every apartment I´ve rented. There was some sort of hole under my kitchen sink leading to the apartment next door -- I could smell it every time my neighbor smoked. <br><br> <br><br>Parking is plentiful. Some people I know (not Duke Manor residents) even park at Duke Manor to walk to Duke when the Duke parking lots are full. <br><br> <br><br>I didn´t have pest (roach or mouse) problems. Living on the third floor probably helped. <br><br> <br><br>I got my entire security deposit back, but not quickly. <br><br> <br><br>Duke Manor allows small pets but charges hundreds of dollars in non-refundable deposits and extra rent. Most people just don´t tell the staff when they have pets, to avoid the charges. <br><br> <br><br>You´ll survive a year at Duke Manor, but it´s not a nice place. There are plenty of better options in Durham.

Resident
2001 - 2002 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/06/2002
High crime, in community-robberies, one murder reported to us while we lived here <br><br> <br><br>Roaches, roaches, roaches. We lived on the bottom floor and were infested with roaches and other insects that loved moisture, pill bugs, camel crickets. they are all too willing to expose everyone to pesticides and have the men come and spray, but for all of those chemicals, the bugs really don´t die off. <br><br> <br><br>Intrusive, they always give you 1 day notice for pesticide spraying, no time to arrange for animal care! They even suggested that it was silly of me to worry about my parakeet being there at the time. They tried to tell me I could leave him in the room as they sprayed. When I called the company directly, they told me otherwise! <br><br> <br><br> <br>The parking lot is always messy, broken glass from the weekends, beer bottles lying around. Even on the playground. <br> <br>Also, lots of strange people knock on our doors. We never open the door for them, but they get nervous and leave when our dog barks. It just makes us nervous having shady people outside our door, knocking. <br> <br> <br>Many of our electrical outlets do not work at all. Some are pulled out of the wall easily when just unplugging something. <br> <br>Lots of holes and cracks, very tiny, but perfect for roaches. <br> <br>Do not expect to move large furniture in easily. Our regular sized couch BARELY made it in, there is a wall in front of you as you walk in, so items need to be able to make the left turn to the living room. <br> <br>Our fridge has had numerous problems. We call maintenance an average of 2 times a month for broken sink pipes (water all over the kitchen), fridge problems, sewage backup from the people next door putting lots of food down the drain, etc. <br> <br>When it rains, the telephone wiring gets noisy, resulting in noise during phone conversations and getting kicked off the internet after 5 minutes of being on. The phone company can´t do anything about it. <br>
